Â Third, when we have problems in our relationships, is helpful to look for ways to improve communication, discuss our concerns and how we want to resolve them, but it may be that the relationship needs to end if there isnâ€™t enough interest in one of the parts or if thereâ€™s verbal or emotional abuse.Â  Consider talking to your boyfriend and set some boundaries regarding appropriate communication.At all times:Â  focus on being kind to yourself and improving your self-esteem: increase self-care activities, do more things that you enjoy, meditate in what gives you peace and make an effort to have more of that in your life.Â Â  At the end, you are the one in control of your life, and you determine who you become.Â¿QuÃ© puedo hacer cuando siento que mi vida estÃ¡ fuera de control?Estuve en un accidente de auto, y fue pÃ©rdida total.Â  Deje mi trabajo de 9 aÃ±os para completar un grado a tiempo completo.Â  Falle una clase, y mi novio piensa que soy estÃºpida, el quiere dejarme.Â  No tengo a donde ir y siento que lo estoy perdiendo todo.Cuando nos sentimos agobiados es importante reconocer donde estamos parados y entender de donde vienen esas emociones. Â Ya que entendemos la fuente de agobio, es importante normalizar las situaciones que lo causaron, y volver a encontrar el balance en nuestra vida.Primero, los accidentes de auto son comunes, y por ser accidentes no son un reflejo de nosotros o nuestras destrezas.Â  Cuando experimentamos accidentes no s sentimos ansiosos, preocupados, y puede que experimentemos algÃºn trauma.Â  Si sientes ansiedad, extrema preocupaciÃ³n habla con tu doctor o terapista al respecto.Â  Segundo, muchas personas fallan clases, tareas, fechas de entrega, pero no se rinden.Â  Tenemos que recordar que fallar es parte del proceso de aprendizaje, y tener el valor de intentarlo de nuevo, es lo que nos da determinaciÃ³n y carÃ¡cter.Â Â  Recuerda que te impulsÃ³ a dejar tu trabajo y canaliza esa energÃ­a en la escuela.Â  Tercero, Â cuando tenemos problemas en las relaciones, es importante comunicar nuestras preocupaciones y diferencias, pero puede ser que la relaciÃ³n termine si no hay interÃ©s mutuo o si hay algÃºn tipo de abuso.Â  Â Considera hablar con tu novio y establecer lÃ­mites respecto a la comunicaciÃ³n apropiada.En todo momento: enfÃ³cate en cuidarte a ti misma y mejorar tu autoestima, aumenta las actividades que te ayudan a sentirte bien, medita sobre lo que te paz y pasa mÃ¡s tiempo practicando esas actividades.

questionTitle: How can I manage my budding anxiety?
questionText: I have been thinking a lot about certain situations and having my worries about what others may think or say.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: I think it's a great idea that you are asking this question now while it's early on.Â The first thing I wonder is what age you are.Â  At different transitions and stages in life, it's really common for anxieties to come out of the woodwork.Â  First time this takes place at a greater level is during adolescence, because a teen's "job" is to figure out who they are within the context of other people.Â  Spikes in anxiety also can also occur after high school when you are leaving the nest and heading to college, or the late twenties when it feels like you are expected to have your life figured out and compare to where others are in their lives.Â  That same scenario can show up in mid-life as well for different reasons depending on the person.Â Â Aside from age, certain circumstances can influence a jump in anxiety, such as a job change, switching schools, moving, opening a business, college finals, etc.Â  Take some time to explore where the anxiety might be coming from and just see what comes up.Â  It may be something you have some control over, or something that you can ask for help from someone else for--especially if it's social anxiety.Â  The more you practice social skills, the more confidence you'll have in the long-run.A metaphor I use with some people is gas for a car.Â  Anxiety is a necessary motivator for action, though you get to decide where to go with that anxiety.Â  An overfilled tank doesn't get you any further than a normally-filled tank, and more gas doesn't mean the gas is in charge of where you go.Â  Applying that to what I know about your situation--how much of that worrying is getting you somewhere, how much is just extra gas, and are the worries changing what you really want to do? Sometimes knowing the makeup of our anxiety gives us more power over how we deal with it, and I think you could for sure get there with some help.

questionTitle: How can I overcome social anxiety?
questionText: I have a fear of talking with people. I don't like to go out to social events. I'm always worrying about someone judging me.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Thanks for reaching out and asking this question.Â Â Social stuff is hard.Â  Even for people that don't have diagnosed social anxiety.Â  Some research outlines that our fear of public speaking is greater than our fear of death.Â  That's hefty!Â  Shame is often the culprit for social anxiety because we think other people will see the flaws in ourselves that we believe are there.Â  I've had experiences where I thought the person thought something awful of me, just to find out it was exactly the opposite.Â  That's how powerful our minds can be!What are other things that people may think of you?Â  Maybe you are very kind and easy to talk to.Â  Maybe you think differently than other people and some people enjoy hearing your perspectives.Â  It's even a possibility that they are worrying about the same things as you, even if they seem very confident.Â  Confidence can be easy to fake if it's how you cope with fear.To work through some of that, it's much better to force yourself out there and have conversations.Â  Avoiding people sends the message to your brain that not only are those situations dangerous (socially), but that you can't handle them.Â  The more you avoid, the harder it gets and the more anxiety is created by just the thought of being around people.Â  Take it moment by moment, too.Â  Thinking about all the conversations you are confronted with in a day is overwhelming.Â  Just focus on getting through each conversation, and give yourself credit for doing that---even if you felt awkward, embarrassed, etc.Â  Social skills can be taught at any stage of life, and there's always room for mistakes.Â  No one in society communicates perfectly and you don't need to put that pressure on yourself.The last thing I'd say is keep at least 1-3 people in your life that feel really good to talk to--like it's not a task.Â  Talking to acquaintances and random people is not to fulfill a need for close connection (unless you end up finding a great friend), but more to feel like you are definitely able to handle conversations without the threat of crippling anxiety.Â  You may even get to a place where you enjoy it (sometimes).Â Â Reach out to people in your life if you need extra support!

questionTitle: How can I stop worrying much?
questionText: I have a bad habit of thinking and worrying about what others may think of me. I really want to stop it and enjoy things.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: We all experience that to a different level, depending on who you ask.Â  It's actually born out of a good quality---prosocialness.Â  When we care what others think of us, we are also attuned to how we are treating them and what's socially right vs wrong.Â  It definitely does feel like it's more about ourselves, however--meaning it feels like we worry about what others think because we don't want to be socially outcast or rejected.Â  That's also (again, to a certain level) a healthy quality.Â  It means you want connection.Â  Connection is crucial to mental health and, according to some available research, physical health.Â Â No matter how mentally healthy or socially confident you are, if you care about connection, you're going to care about what people think of you to an extent.Â  So the work here is to figure out what worry is warranted vs what is just causing you suffering.Â  A good way to tell the difference here is to write it out in list form.Â  Write out all the socially-anxious thoughts you have and scale them from "needed" or "helpful" to "unnecessary" or "unhelpful".Â  Some may fall in the gray area here.Â  For example: if you worry that others think you are inconsiderate, so you often say sorry---weed out what's actually inconsiderate vs what you feel is maybe inconsiderate because you feel like a burden to others.Â  Getting in someone's personal space would warrant some worry and an apology.Â  Asking for help when you need it is something you don't have to apologize for.Â Â Something else to consider here is there's probably some underlying shame.Â  Shame is a cluster of really tough feelings and if it had a voice, it'd say things like, "you're not good enough", "you aren't likeable", "you are annoying and no one wants to be around you", etc.Â  Those feelings typically create the worry you experience about others.Â  Shame survives and is strengthened by the attention you give to it.Â  The more you compete with it, the less powerful it becomes.Â  Sometimes that comes in the form of noticing the wonderful qualities in yourself.Â  Sometimes it takes practice putting yourself out there when it's really scary.Â  No matter what, shame's nemesis is connection---to yourself and to others.Â  That's how you prove it's wrong.Â  Try not to take shame at face value!If you are struggling with using these techniques or just don't know if they are right for you, a counselor can help you out and give you a more individualized approach.Â  Sometimes it's just figuring out that specific formula that works for you that makes all the difference.Â  And of course, counseling is built on a strong connection.I wish you all the best!

questionTitle: How can I stop worrying much?
questionText: I have a bad habit of thinking and worrying about what others may think of me. I really want to stop it and enjoy things.
therapistInfo: Daniel Kelley-PetersenMental Health and Career Counselor
answerText: Thinking about what others think of us is a natural tendency. Human beings are social creatures and rely on feedback from the outside world of people, places, and things to let us know more about ourselves. We also have an inner voice, dialogue, conscience, etc. that helps us to determine the path for us. Often, when someone is worried about the external feedback, and focuses on this as the sole source of information, it can create a dependency that can become problematic. Balance is key to so many things in life. Your own voice is powerful and has strength to provide you the enjoyment you seek. Don't discount it and rely only on the voices of others.

questionTitle: How can I stop repetitive thoughts and feel confident again?
questionText: I have been repeating the same thought pattern for seven years and have completely lost control of any situation. I am in my early 30s, and I feel like I am trapped in my body, mind, soul, and house because I feel embarrassed to go anywhere or talk to anyone.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: There's SO much help for repetitive thoughts in the counseling world!Â Â The one thing I'd for sure ask if we met in person is what those repetitive thought patterns look like.Â  Some repetitive thoughts are more like obsessive thoughts.Â  For example, that may mean that every time you leave a room, your obsessive thought is to switch the light on and off 5 times.Â  Or every time you touch a door handle, you think about the germs you came into contact with and washing your hands multiple times.Â  Sometimes it's more about the same thoughts repeating about bad things that may happen, or critical thoughts we have about ourselves.Â  Your statement about "feeling confident again" gives me the sense that maybe you struggle with the ways in which you think about yourself.Assuming it's obsessive thoughts: exposure and response prevention therapy is an excellent form of treatment.Â  Typically, obsessive thoughts influence compulsions, which usually show up as very strict, repetitive rituals in order to manage anxiety.Â  Exposure and response prevention exposes you to the things that increase anxiety, while response prevention helps you to sit through that anxiety response without performing a compulsion.Â  For example, you touch a door handle.Â  Your anxiety increases.Â  You obsess about the germs you came into contact with and have a strong urge to wash your hands multiple times.Â  Instead, you sit through the anxiety, let the anxiety decrease on its own, and slowly unpair that anxious response with the behavior.Â  The more you do this, the more it breaks up those thinking/behavior patterns that make you feel chained to them.Assuming it's self-critical thoughts: cognitive-behavioral therapy can work well here.Â  Everyone's brain has a default track, that when met with struggle, plays over and over like a broken record.Â  The more you give into that, the more it plays.Â  The trick here is creating a competing track, or turning the volume up on a track that boosts your confidence instead of shooting it down.Â  Some ways to do that are really identifying and writing down what those repetitive thoughts are.Â  You probably already know them pretty well if they repeat often.Â  Then next to them--write out a line that has an heir of confidence and/or gentleness.Â  For example, if your repetitive thought is that you are a failure, you may write out a sentence that is something like:Â  I may be struggling greatly with this situation, yet I am still trying super hard to get better and that's definitely not a failure.Â  Every separate repetitive thought can have its own competing sentence.Â  Initially, these new thoughts will feel weird, foreign, and maybe even like they don't do anything.Â  Give it time.Â  The repetitive thoughts have had years to grow, so these new thoughts need time, too.Â  They are, literally, new pathways in the brain and the more they are traveled, the stronger they will get.I'm also sensing that there's a combination of anxiety and depression.Â  I would assume that you are probably feeling pretty cut off from the world if you don't want to talk to anyone.Â  That can be so lonely and isolating.Â  Because connection is basically crucial for healing, it may be very beneficial for you to see a counselor or find a support that feels safe to you.Â  Counselors are usually trained very well in these types of issues and some offer telehealth if you are having trouble leaving your home.Â  It might feel scary and strange at first, but you are in a lot of pain and deserve healing.Hope this helps a bit.Â  Go with your gut and do what you feel is right for you!Â  I wish you all the best.

questionTitle: What should I do about my stress before track meets?
questionText: I am on the track and softball team. My school is small, so I play all four sports it offers. I feel obligated to do track because I'm not a horrible runner, and my dad wants me to. The catch is is that the days before a track meet and the morning of, I get sick and cry.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Seems like you have some confidence in your track abilities, but feel pressured by your dad to continue something you don't really enjoy.Â  Are you maybe worried about disappointing your dad, or is it something about track itself that upsets you or overwhelms your body?When we try to push through stuff that's too much for our bodies (whether that's physical or emotional), that stress will show up no matter how hard we try to bury it.Â  Â Sometimes that shows up as crying or irritation, other times that shows up as physical symptoms.Â  Â For you, it could be both.Â  Based on the symptoms showing up days before a meet, it could be more emotional since it comes so long beforehand.Â Â I'm assuming you are very active already, so extra exercise probably isn't too helpful and may only put more stress on your body.Â  Do you feel like you ever get a chance to truly relax?Â  Always running on overdrive with little gas is exhausting.Â  Try giving yourself permission during the period before the track meets to just do something that slows you down.Â  Doesn't have to be super long--even 10-15 minutes a day could give your brain and body a very needed break from that go-go-go lifestyle.Pay attention to your sleep as well.Â  I don't know anything about your nightly routine, but if you are struggling to sleep that could enhance the symptoms of anxiety before your meets.Â  Some calm activities before bed could help here.Of course, you could try talking with your dad about whats happening if you think he'd be able to support your needs.Â  That's not always possible, and if not, no worries.Â  There's a lot you can do to get through what's happening.Â  If you have another caregiver in the picture that feels approachable, you could talk to him/her about how you are feeling.Â  Also, take a look at strategies for performance anxiety online.Â  Even if you don't have that particular type of anxiety, the strategies are really great and can at least help a little if you are still engaging in track.

questionTitle: What should I do about my stress before track meets?
questionText: I am on the track and softball team. My school is small, so I play all four sports it offers. I feel obligated to do track because I'm not a horrible runner, and my dad wants me to. The catch is is that the days before a track meet and the morning of, I get sick and cry.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Does anyone notice that you get sick and cry on track meet days?Have you told anyone?From what you write, as much as you would like to please your school and dad, something within you doesn't quite want to fully follow through.Step one in life always is to know what you want and what your limits are. Â  It already is difficult to avoid listening to your body.Try understanding what is difficult in telling your father that you'd like doing as he wishes, only are not able to do so because you are emotionally and physically distraught on the days you have track.After finishing the season for this year with your school's track team, then expect to concentrate on taking care of your own need to not do track.Hopefully your father will understand and care about your problem. Â  If he does not and track is more important than your well being, then you have a different problem entirely.

questionTitle: What should I do about my stress before track meets?
questionText: I am on the track and softball team. My school is small, so I play all four sports it offers. I feel obligated to do track because I'm not a horrible runner, and my dad wants me to. The catch is is that the days before a track meet and the morning of, I get sick and cry.
therapistInfo: Amy NolanYour journey to wellness starts here!
answerText: It sounds like you are no longer committed to track emotionally. Â It can be hard to talk to your dad about this, but he may think you love track and may not know you are getting so upset the days of meets. Â An idea would be to first write a letter to your dad to see what feelings come out and then preparing to speak with him. Â I think he will appreciate your honesty and maybe this conversation will bring you relief and also time to find something you really will enjoy.

questionTitle: What can I do about my severe social anxiety when my family doesn't believe in it?
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: I'm so sorry you aren't being taken seriously.Â  I hope you have at least one person in your life that believes you and will listen to you.Â  Sometimes when family members don't give us a chance to be heard, we can find someone in our lives that makes us feel like we matter.Â  If you struggle with finding that, a counselor could be that person for you.Other things you could try include finding ways to calm your mind and body.Â  There's a lot of apps available with calming scenes and soundscapes, such as Calm and Headspace.Â  St. John's Wart is also pretty popular for working with the symptoms of anxiety and depression and is available without a prescription.Just as a last note--you don't need your family to believe what you are going through to get better.Â  It could for sure make it harder, but if you can get through severe anxiety, you can totally get through the healing process.

questionTitle: Can anxiety make me say foul language?
questionText: I'm scared that my anxiety will make me say foul language. I don't want to say those words though. I'm only a teen and all my friends curse, but I don't want to. I don't know what to do.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: It's definitely possible that your response to anxiety is to swear, though you don't have to feel controlled by that reaction.Â Â As a teen, you're developing your identity based on what feels right to you and what doesn't.Â  It's OK to be different than your friends, and just being around swearing doesn't mean you will for sure pick up that habit.Â  What is it that connects your anxiety to swearing?Â  If it feels like your automatic response might be to curse, you could try picking some words that don't go against your values to use as a default when you are upset.Â Â You could also work directly with calming your anxiety, maybe in ways that make you feel in control.Â  Breathing exercises as well as thought replacement (replacing an unhelpful thought with a helpful one) are good for that.Â  Whatever you try, I wish you the best of luck!

questionTitle: Can anxiety make me think I heard something about me?
questionText: When I'm around people, I sometimes think someone has made a comment to me or asked me to do something. I will be focusing on something else and then randomly think I hear something about me. I never know if it was actually said.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Sure can!Â  Especially social anxiety or anxiety in the form of paranoia.Â Â Are there any patterns to when or where this happens most?Â  Does it ever happen with people you feel safe and comfortable with?Â  Or only when you are in an uncomfortable social setting?Â  If you notice any patterns, you can focus in on the anxiety surrounding them and build coping skills to help you get through those moments (if that's what would feel helpful).You could also seek help and talk to someone about what's happening to get a better assessment of your situation and more personalized techniques.Â  There's many counselors out there that are great at working with anxiety!

questionTitle: Can anxiety make me think I heard something about me?
questionText: When I'm around people, I sometimes think someone has made a comment to me or asked me to do something. I will be focusing on something else and then randomly think I hear something about me. I never know if it was actually said.
therapistInfo: Jennifer GerlachYour Story Matters
answerText: Anxiety can absolutely make you think you heard something about you. When we are on high alert, we tend to look for threats and often the greatest threats we experience on a daily basis are social in nature.Â  To some extent this is normal, for example, when people experience late onset deafness, they often will worry people are talking about them (and usually not good things) because our brains tend to jump to that. Of course, I'm not saying you are going deaf or anything, just giving an example. Counseling can help you work through this anxiety. It may also be helpful to reach out to a counselor to rule out if there may be other things going on. Sometimes things like paranoia can blend in with anxiety, which is a very distressing experience. But both are absolutely treatable. Wishing you the best!

questionTitle: Can anxiety make me think I heard something about me?
questionText: When I'm around people, I sometimes think someone has made a comment to me or asked me to do something. I will be focusing on something else and then randomly think I hear something about me. I never know if it was actually said.
therapistInfo: Ben BraaksmaMental Health Counselor
answerText: It sounds like you are having difficulty knowing if people are saying things to you, or if you only thought someone was talking to you, and this is anxiety producing. It's understandable that it could be confusing and/or a bit scary to be unsure if people are speaking to you or not. It's hard to say exactly what is going on from just this description, but if you can work with a competent therapist, you may be able to get more insight into what is happening, get clarity about your social interactions, and develop some ways to deal with the anxiety.

questionTitle: Why do I always feel anxious?
questionText: It's especially bad at night time. I am scared of sleeping alone.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Night is hard for a lot of people, so you are definitely not alone here.Â Â Has anything scary ever happened to you at night?Â  Answering that question may give you the "why" of where that's coming from.Â  If you haven't had a bad experience at night, it may just be the time when you have nothing to do, which allows more intense thoughts and feelings to surface.Â Â Here's a couple things to try:One thing you could do is sit down a couple hours before you go to bed and journal (if you can).Â  Try to reduce any distractions and just go for it.Â  The purpose of this is to slow down well before you go to bed, expressing some of the anxiety from the day.Â  Also take note of the things you can tackle that day vs what can wait until later.Â  This gives your brain a chance to sort through some of the "planning" type of anxiety that commonly comes up when you are trying to sleep.Another thing you can do is make a list of the things you have control over.Â  Anxiety is really good at putting everything you feel out of control of on a giant metaphorical projection screen.Â  Try projecting some of the things you have control over instead.Â  For example--you have total control over breathing patterns, what you choose to wear the next day, what you pay attention to if you go for a walk, etc.Â  You also have control over how you personalize that list to what matters to you.Â  Mindfulness is a great way to focus on how you control your breath, and also how letting go of breathing doesn't stop your body from doing what it's always doing to keep you alive.Â  Any google search will bring up lots of information on this!Something to remember is that experiencing anxiety is OK.Â  It doesn't mean something is necessarily wrong.Â  Anxiety is sometimes just a feeling that comes up without much of a cause.Â  If you can't identify that cause, it's probably because of a little misinterpretation in the brain.Â  Mindfulness can definitely help with that.

questionTitle: Why do I always feel anxious?
questionText: It's especially bad at night time. I am scared of sleeping alone.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Being able to know you feel anxiety and write about it, is the first step to addressing and handling it!Generally, anxiety is deep fear of not being able to handle what comes up in life.Â Â Somehow the person was insufficiently nurtured and so felt Â insecure when very young.Usually the person had to fend on at least a psychological and emotional level for themselves before reaching an age when doing so would have been reasonable.Their inner feeling of overwhelmed from when very young, hasn't faced the reality that the grown person is now capable, even if this takes some practice.Â Try asking yourself what you are afraid of and theorize how you would handle these situations as a grown person.Also, sometimes anxiety comes from feeling lonely. Â This loneliness is reminiscent of the loneliness that the grown person now, felt when being left to take care of situations as a child which were too difficult and complex for any child to address.

questionTitle: Why do I see and hear things that are not real?
questionText: Iâ€™m a teenager. I am almost always paranoid. Recently, I started to think they watch. I keep seeing in the corner of my eye someone moving. The other night, I heard breathing in my room, and my eyes focused on a black shape. I turned on the lights, but no one was there.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: I've worked with teens in a day treatment program for about 6 years now and it's been a theme that a lot of them see dark figures out of the corner of their eyes.Â  Pretty common with teens that have endured trauma--physical or sexual abuse, witnessing domestic violence, etc.Â  We don't have a lot of information on why this happens, but it's theorized that the brain projects the emotions outside of us in the form of dark figures--maybe just as a reflection of what is existing on the inside of the brain or even to give some emotional relief.Â  When we have kids that have experienced those types of hallucinations, they almost always disappear once they have worked through their trauma.Â Â Sometimes visual and auditory hallucinations are symptoms of mental health disorders as well, though that's pretty rare for those to start as early as the teens years.Â  It's best to have your symptoms checked out by a medical professional and maybe even a psychiatrist to get a better idea of what may be happening.Â  Â Are you or have you been taking any medications that could potentially have these side effects?Â  If you do visit one or both professionals, make sure you or a caregiver is giving them all the details about your symptoms so they can help you as much as possible.A big question here is what is your sleep like?Â  Lack of sleep is notorious for causing hallucinations and can become severe after only a few nights of sleep deprivation.Â  If you are having trouble sleeping, that may be another topic to discuss with your doctor.No matter what it is, it's obviously scary otherwise you wouldn't feel paranoid.Â  Try some techniques to calm yourself a few times during the day, like deep breathing or movement-based strategies like yoga.Â  Whatever speaks to you.Â  And remember that while you are figuring this issue out, the hallucinations can't hurt you even if they get stronger.Glad you are reaching out to get some help!

questionTitle: Why do I see and hear things that are not real?
questionText: Iâ€™m a teenager. I am almost always paranoid. Recently, I started to think they watch. I keep seeing in the corner of my eye someone moving. The other night, I heard breathing in my room, and my eyes focused on a black shape. I turned on the lights, but no one was there.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Sounds like anxiety and a strong imagination are getting the better of you.Do you sometimes have less confidence in yourself than you'd like to have? Â Or doubt and question yourself in matters which in hindsight were easier to solve than you realized at first?These are two examples of anxiety blurring your vision of a situation. Â Possibly imagining sights and sounds is also blurring an accurate assessment of what actually takes place in your room at night.Addressing anxiety is best done indirectly, not directly.Concentrate on knowing more of your reasons to question yourself so deeply in the first place. Â Being a teenager certainly adds to overall anxiety. Â And you may have good reason from your growing up personal history to have more than an average amount of self-doubt.If you felt humiliated, mocked, ignored, blamed, any type of interaction with meaningful people in your life while you were younger, then this probably set the groundwork to not have faith in yourself.Awareness of where you feel vulnerable is the first step to deliberately changing this into a strength!

questionTitle: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
questionText: I've been like this ever since I was in school; back then I transferred to another school. Now I'm thinking about changing my job.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Is there a certain problem you feel about living the way you describe?As long as you feel satisfied with how your life is unfolding then youâ€™re making wise decisions.If you feel tension or that somehow doing as you describe is wrong, then the first step is to identify the way you feel your methodology described above has a role in working against your best interest.Basically, define what is problematic in order to address it.

questionTitle: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
questionText: I've been like this ever since I was in school; back then I transferred to another school. Now I'm thinking about changing my job.
therapistInfo: Nicole StoneAnxiety, relationship crisis, and the separation/divorce experience.
answerText: There's a quote I love that says, "Wherever you go, there you are" and the book by the same name by Jon Kabat-Zinn may be very helpful for you. The thing about changing things up when they get tough is that they often aren't the things that need changing. The awesome (and challenging) thing about it is that when you work on the internal aspects that may need attention, you can learn to find a sense of centeredness that comes with practicing mindfulness and asking yourself who you really are and want to be. Through this deeper work, you can actually be in the midst of chaos and still feel that calm and peace within yourself. If you look for support in this journey from a counselor or therapist, I'd recommend looking for someone offering Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) or Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (MCBT). Also helpful may be the online program of Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MSBR) found here.Â There are in-person programs across the country, but this online self-guided version is free and a great resource!

questionTitle: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
questionText: I've been like this ever since I was in school; back then I transferred to another school. Now I'm thinking about changing my job.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: It's great that you are at least aware of what pushes you to seek change in your life.If you were in session with me, one of the first things I'd explore is what "tough" means for you.Â  Is it relationship issues with other people?Â  Or tasks related to your job?Â  Or is it something else?Â  It's important to know what you may be trying to escape in order to work with it.Â  For example, if you tend to make changes when you are faced with a commitment, then there would be something about commitment that scared you and the work would be focused there.Â Â One thing to think about is that most people tend to run from things that they believe they can't handle or get through.Â  Could this be happening in your situation?Â  If it is, there could be some underlying fears present that you are incompetent or you will fail.Â  What's interesting about that is that some people avoid change for the very same reasons.Â  It's actually quite amazing that you handle so much change in your life and have for a very long time.Â  That shows you can handle a lot!Â Â The last thought I have is that the more you push through the tough stuff, the more you will have confidence in your ability to do that.Â  You don't have to feel confident to start the process--in fact, many people feel very vulnerable and terrified sticking with decisions that are out of their comfort zone.Â  Having social support, even if it's just one person, is so important when you're facing your fears.Â  That could mean counseling, or a partner, friend, family member, etc.Â  Doing it alone is another level of tough.You may be at the point in your life where you are just seeking some answers and aren't feeling ready to address what's happening and that's OK.Â  No one wants to go blindly into this kind of work.Â  There's no rush to figure it all out right now.Â  Give yourself some time to let things unfold!

questionTitle: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
questionText: I've been like this ever since I was in school; back then I transferred to another school. Now I'm thinking about changing my job.
therapistInfo: Vivian D. Echevarria Guzman, MSC, LPC-S, NCCBilingual Licensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Many times when things become difficult to manage, is because we are getting out of our comfort zone, so we seek growth and change.Â  Coping with the difficulties does make you more resilientÂ and helps you to build the confidence you need to solve problems in the future.Â Now I wonder:Â  are things getting tough in a way that you are not able to resolve them? Â Do you need to move or change to save yourself or prevent any harm? If so, it is OK to know when to remove ourselves form situations that harm us more than helping us. Â Â On the other hand, are the things getting tough because you need to learn a new skill?Â  If so, how can you learn them and is there someone who can help you overcome this challenge?Â  I help my clients to identify their strengths and areas where they can achieve growth, things like polishing up your resume and evaluate new job opportunities could help you discover a new you.If you would like to engage in counseling, I am licensed in Texas and Puerto Rico, you can contact me at 787-466-5478.Â Cada vez que las cosas se ponen difÃ­ciles, hago cambios en mi vida.He sido asÃ­ desde que estaba en la escuela; antes me transferÃ­a de escuela.Â  Ahora pienso cambiar de trabajo.Muchas veces cuando las situaciones se tornan en difÃ­ciles de manejar, es porque nos sacan de nuestra zona de comodidad, con el propÃ³sito de buscar el cambio y el crecimiento.Â  Manejar las dificultades si te vuelve mÃ¡s resistente, y desarrolla tu autoestima para que puedas resolver problemas en el futuro. Â  Â Ahora, te pregunto: Â¿se estÃ¡n poniendo las cosas difÃ­ciles al punto que no puedes manejarlas?Â  Â¿Necesitas removerte de la situaciÃ³n para evitar que te hagan daÃ±o? Si es asÃ­, entonces estÃ¡ bien reconocer cuando nos debemos remover de una situaciÃ³n daÃ±ina que nos daÃ±a mÃ¡s de lo que nos permite crecer. O por el otro lado, Â¿Se estÃ¡n poniendo las cosas difÃ­ciles porque necesitas a prender una nueva destreza?Â Â  Si es asÃ­, Â¿cÃ³mo puedes aprender esa destreza y quien te puede ayudar?Ayudo a mis clientes a identificar sus fortalezas y Ã¡reas de crecimiento, el actualizar y pulir tu resume junto con explorar opciones de empleo, te puede llevar a descubrir nuevos talentos en ti.Si te gustarÃ­a hacer una cita, soy Consejera Profesional Licenciada en Texas y en Puerto Rico, llama al 787-466-5478.

questionTitle: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
questionText: I've been like this ever since I was in school; back then I transferred to another school. Now I'm thinking about changing my job.
therapistInfo: Lauren Ostrowski, MA, LPC, NCC, BC-TMH, CCTP, CCHI tailor my therapeutic approach to each client's strengths and goals
answerText: Sometimes changes make sense. It may be helpful to talk to someone who you trust to get a sense of whether the changes that you are making are those that are considered adaptable or important changes that allow us all to grow. Another possibility is that you are changing things in an effort to get away from something that is uncomfortable or difficult. There are many other possibilities along this continuum.I would ask you to consider the following:What is leading you to want to change your job?What feelings are associated with this change? (Happy, sad, scared, anxious/nervous, confused, motivated, etc.)How is the job that you are looking to transfer to going to be better or different? Are the concerns that you have now going to travel with you?If you are hesitating to get another perspective (from trusted friends or family or some sort of career advisor in your area), where is the hesitation coming from?

questionTitle: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
questionText: I've been like this ever since I was in school; back then I transferred to another school. Now I'm thinking about changing my job.
therapistInfo: Jessica DobbsTherapist
answerText: I recommend that you make a list of all the reasons you should change your life and all of the reasons you shouldn't change your life. Can the problem you are in be fixed? Is there others you can lean on for support? Are there other people you know who have been through a similar experience and are willing to share their story with you? It is important to rely on your support network to help you get multiple points of view. If you believe you need additional help, I suggest seeing a professional.

questionTitle: How can I wake up without having an anxiety attack?
questionText: I have these dreams of men, and they always seem to try to hurt me. It's gotten so bad that I first wake at 4:30, then 4:45, and finally stay awake by 6:00. I'm always the last one to fall asleep and the first to wake. I hate falling asleep. The longest I've went without sleep is three days.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: No wonder you are scared to sleep if this is what you are going through.My first thought is that it's possible your dreams are your brain's way of trying to process something that scares you or has scared you.Â  There's not a lot of research on the purpose of dreams, but one theory is that stuff you don't want to deal with consciously is able to come through via your unconscious brain as a dream (or nightmare).Â  Another theory is more of Gestalt nature, where all your dream figures represent a part of you--for example, the part of you being attacked would be the side of you that feels weak, whereas the attacker is the side of you that you feel is bad or evil.Â  Either way, your reactions are definitely legit because nightmares tend to flood the brain in a pretty emotionally raw form.I am also curious if you had trouble sleeping before you started having these dreams. Is it because of these nightmares that sleep is an issue, or have the sleep issues been a part of your life longer than the dreams?Â  It may not mean a whole lot no matter what order they came in, but it would be interesting to know if the catalyst was actually the dreams to begin with.Â  The big question here is if not having these nightmares would improve your sleep and lessen your anxiety about sleeping, overall.As for the anxiety attacks, there's a lot here you can try.Â  Your brain is seeing sleep, nightmares, or both as a threat.Â  The way to signal safety to your brain is to practice some relaxation techniques--mindful breathing can be helpful or if you find it hard to sit still, you can do some walking mindfulness.Â  Maybe you've heard of the Calm app--it's so great for sleep issues.Â  They have sleep stories and soundscapes, as well as guided breathing exercises.Â Â This is speaking more to the thinking process, but remind yourself that the dreams aren't real and they can't hurt you.Â  That doesn't mean you won't have anxiety and you have to fully believe it, it just means that you don't have to get caught up in the fear response.Â  You also mention that they "try" to hurt you.Â  Have you ever done things to fight them off? Or do you run?Â  It's OK if your response is to freeze--I'm just curious how you view yourself in that dream.Â  If you are feeling powerless (which would be normal) it may be worth your time to imagine how you want to fight them off.Â  What weapons would you choose?Â  What would escape look like?Â  Imagining you in charge may help change your experience of the dreams.Also remember that even though panic attacks feel awful, they won't hurt you.Â  It's a really terrifying feeling to be trapped in your body during an attack, but the response is meant to get us out of danger even though there is no real threat.Â  If you do a google search for panic attack help sites, there's so many that detail more of this response and how to move through an attack.Â Â Of course, seeing a counselor might be beneficial if you are sensing that there's something bigger underlying the dreams.Â  Sometimes just having someone listen and understand can ease some suffering.I hope that helps and you find something that works for you!

questionTitle: How can I wake up without having an anxiety attack?
questionText: I have these dreams of men, and they always seem to try to hurt me. It's gotten so bad that I first wake at 4:30, then 4:45, and finally stay awake by 6:00. I'm always the last one to fall asleep and the first to wake. I hate falling asleep. The longest I've went without sleep is three days.
therapistInfo: Jennifer GerlachYour Story Matters
answerText: That is awful! I am sure you are ready to start getting some rest. It's normal for us to wake a few times in the night, however, when we are dealing with high anxiety or stress, those times can turn into being up most night. Given that you are having these repeated dreams, I am wondering what might be going on in your life either nowÂ  or in the past that could be triggering stress or maybe memories. It can help to draw the dream out in the morning or even to look for metaphor. In the long run, seeking counseling can help you sort all that outIn the meantime, self-soothing strategies may help you in the night when you wake and can't get back to sleep. This can be anything with your senses----getting a snack like tea and focusing on that taste, smelling something pleasant, listening to some relaxing music, looking through a magazine, taking a shower. Anything you can think of that might help you relax. If it involves needing to get up, that's okay! Getting out of bed can actually help you get out of that mind space and helps you associate your bed with relaxation/sleep vs anxiety making it more likely you will fall asleep onceÂ  you lay down.

questionTitle: How can I wake up without having an anxiety attack?
questionText: I have these dreams of men, and they always seem to try to hurt me. It's gotten so bad that I first wake at 4:30, then 4:45, and finally stay awake by 6:00. I'm always the last one to fall asleep and the first to wake. I hate falling asleep. The longest I've went without sleep is three days.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: The good news about your dreams is that your fears are right at the surface of your mind so you can study them and release some of the harm from the terrifying experiences you had which created these bad memories in the first place.The bad news is the feelings themselves are sickening.Probably a therapist would be very helpful for guiding you to unfold these uneasy feelings and their source.This type of deep work is easier with emotional support from someone. Â A therapist can give you this plus is knowledgeable about dynamics of someone having been emotionally harmed by another.Or, read a lot online and find out which articles resonate with your emotions.Luckily people are willing to express personal stories of recuperating a sense of peace and safety after being violated by someone.

questionTitle: Why do I have panic attacks when I carry my baby?
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Has something scary ever happened when you were carrying your baby before you had panic attacks?Â  Could have to do with fear of incompetence as a parent, but may be something unrelated.For example, if you got some really bad news when you were carrying your child, your brain may pair those two events together.Â Â Or could it be that the feeling of pressure on your body sets off an anxiety response for you?Â  Do you have panic attacks when holding your baby sitting down? Or is it just when you are standing/walking?Â  Paying attention to when exactly its hitting you could give some clues about what is triggering that response.Another thing I'm wondering is if your baby either cries when you are carrying him/her, or if you carry him/her mostly in response to the baby crying.Â  I'm not sure if you are mom or dad here, but women especially have a very physical response to babies crying.Â  You can physically see this if you are breastfeeding because it triggers the lactation process.Â  But it also can trigger some pretty hefty anxiety.Â  The reason for this makes sense--if we felt nothing when our babies started to cry, we wouldn't be very motivated to attend to them to meet their needs.Â  If baby is crying when you are holding him/her, it might be triggering that anxiety response and feel a lot of pressure to respond to your baby's needs.Â  If that turns into a pattern, your body basically expects to feel that way and may respond habitually with panic, even in the absence of baby crying.If you don't think it's related to your baby being upset, you could still be experiencing that habitual response of panic, and especially if you are worried about having a panic attack (which ironically can induce panic).Â Â A counselor may be able to help you untangle what's happening to you and some ways to work through that.Â  It can be really scary to sit through a panic attack, though there are so many techniques to help.Â  People have written some really great articles on getting through an attack, and there are other resources you can use like apps (Calm, Headspace, PanicShield, etc.), and youtube has really great videos as well.I also want to mention that if you avoid carrying your baby because of anxiety, that would be a normal response.Â  Many people who have panic attacks tend to feel guilty about the things that they end up unable to do because of the anxiety they feel.Â  Remember you are doing the best you can.Â  You are reaching out, you are concerned.Â  Guilt about how you deal with anxiety really complicates your experience further, so try to practice some self-compassion if you are going through this.Â  Kristin Neff has some great resources for that if you are interested:Â https://self-compassion.org/.I hope all the best for you!

questionTitle: Why do I have panic attacks when I carry my baby?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Maybe you're fearful that you don't have enough skill or ability to take care of your child.Since you're writing your question it is likely you really do care and are capable, only have self-doubts as to your abilities.

questionTitle: How can I deal with this anxiety that keeps me up all night?
questionText: I've been having horrible anxiety for the last week. I can't sleep. I get a sense of doom, and it's hard to breathe. I feel like nothing I do makes it better.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: That really sucks to go through.Â  There are tons of ways to work with anxiety, both directly and indirectly that can help with what you are dealing with.Do you think you may be experiencing a panic attack?Â  Sounds like you are feeling some dread about what will happen to you and physical symptoms common with attacks.Â  Panic attacks are the body's way of trying to alert you to danger, whether that is real or perceived.Â  It's not something your body does against you, but instead to keep you safe by keeping you in a state where you could react quickly (run, fight, etc.).Â  This can happen even if there aren't any real threats and you logically know you are safe.Â  Even if you aren't having panic attacks, that heightened anxiety can still feel really awful and exhausting.What have you done so far that is not working?Â  When the brain is in that "danger" mode, talking it down tends to be unsuccessful--this is very evident in bounds of research we have on how the brain functions.Â  The part of the brain that senses threats and triggers anxiety responses reacts more effectively to body signals to relax---such as controlled breathing.Â  Mindfulness breathing techniques have a lot of value for this reason and there are many options available (apps like Calm and Headspace, youtube guided videos, etc).Â  Try to keep in mind that having anxiety doesn't mean that you are actually in any danger, and mindfulness is not meant to be an escape.Â  It does help to regulate and make you feel more in control of your body.Â  Your anxiety will always come back down--you can even track it to see the real-time changes that happen.Â  It's normal for it to rise and fall a few times during a panic attack, so if you notice a rise, it has no meaning other than that you're body is normally going through it's anxiety response.I think seeing a doctor is a great idea to rule out any other issues happening within the body.Â  Some medical issues can materialize as anxiety and depression.Â  Depending on your symptoms, they may even suggest a medication developed for these issues.Anxiety is one of the top researched symptoms, so we do have tons of research available on what works and what's less effective.Â  We know that talking alone doesn't reduce the body's fear response, unless talking is the method of exposure (talking about a traumatic experience, talking within a group if you have social anxiety, etc.).Â  For the brain to learn you are safe, it takes experience via exposure while riding the wave of anxiety.Â  For example, if you fear vomiting, you would expose yourself to things that remind you of vomiting and breathe through the anxiety you feel without avoiding the triggers.Â  That would teach your brain that those triggers are actually benign, and would no longerÂ  create that panicky response. It'd be difficult to say what that may look like for you, or even if you need that, but it could be worth connecting with a counselor (even online) to discuss these options.Â Â The brain is always flexible to some degree to change, so hang in there while you figure it all out!

questionTitle: How can I deal with this anxiety that keeps me up all night?
questionText: I've been having horrible anxiety for the last week. I can't sleep. I get a sense of doom, and it's hard to breathe. I feel like nothing I do makes it better.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Anxiety is usually a sign of a current problem to which familiar emotional patterns of feeling similarly upset, attach themselves.Try to understand more about who you are, what you like, feel uneasy about, especially your deeper emotions of being emotionally harmed or injured by meaningful people.Anxiety is best addressed indirectly by understanding and kindly accepting previous hurt and fears from long ago.Once you feel at ease with dynamics of past situations then the current anxiety will decrease. Â This is because you will have adjusted and found new ways of handling otherwise frightening and overwhelming interactions and involvements with others.

questionTitle: What is social anxiety?
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Almost everyone has some level of social anxiety.Â  Because we need others to survive (this is overwhelmingly true in the research) it makes sense we worry about what others think.Â Â The thing to know is that social anxiety exists on a spectrum.Â  Some people experience very little, some more, and some feel debilitated by their social anxiety.Â  This can be influenced by past social experiences, including those within your family.Â  Going through trauma can make it more likely you will experience higher levels of social anxiety.The ways in which we regulate social anxiety can be really backward.Â  Because we are worried about embarrassment or judgment from others, we tend to overthink about our responses and react to people awkwardly, which robs us from our spontaneous responses and canÂ  make people feel uncomfortable around us.Â  That doesn't always mean people are judging you, but it can still get in the way of genuine connection.Â Ruminating about what others think of you doesn't always mean you have a disorder.Â  However, if it is interfering with your functioning in any setting, that may be a sign that you could benefit from help.Â  You can always seek help no matter what level of social anxiety you have.With the condition of the nation right now, there aren't many groups running in person, but social anxiety groups are shown to be super effective for reduction of symptoms.Â  There may even be some online groups you could partake in if you think you could benefit.

questionTitle: What is social anxiety?
therapistInfo: Ian Palombo#ThoughtMediator & #LifeUntangler
answerText: Anxiety is not your fault or caused by anything you have or havenâ€™t done. According to theÂ National Alliance on Mental Illness, 40 million adults, or 18% of Americans, experience an anxiety disorder.Â If you are suffering from social anxiety you may experience the following:Constant feelings of dread about social situations;A pounding or racing heart when interacting with others;Â Anticipating the worst aboutÂ interactions with others, regardless of evidence;Physical symptoms like headaches, sweating, shakes and jumpiness, trouble concentrating, a frequent need to urinate and stomach uneasinessThoughtsÂ like,Â â€œItâ€™s safer to stay at home..."Fear of beingÂ away from a bathroom or medical servicesI know that anxiety can come with a stigma, and that may have stopped you from seeking the care you need in the past. Reach out to a counselor today.

questionTitle: What is social anxiety?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Social anxiety means feeling very uneasy in social situations. Â Often people are fearful of being judged, rejected, criticized, mocked, any bad feeling you can think of, even before they make any approach to someone in the group.Social anxiety is a fear someone has about being treated poorly without any sign which justifies feeling this way.If you walk into a group of people which specifically has a sign of not wanting to accept anyone who hasn't been part of the group for at least a dozen years, then walking into this group would justifiably trigger anxiety.If you walk into a business or organization meeting which assumes anyone who has an interest in the purpose of the group is welcome, and you do, and you feel anxiety imagining you'll fall short of expectations, is social anxiety.

questionTitle: What is social anxiety?
therapistInfo: Lauren Ostrowski, MA, LPC, NCC, BC-TMH, CCTP, CCHI tailor my therapeutic approach to each client's strengths and goals
answerText: Social anxiety is fear of social situations where someone is exposed to the public scrutiny of others. It could include things like having conversations with people you don't know, being observed, or public speaking, etc.You can find more information here: https://socialanxietyinstitute.org/what-is-social-anxiety

questionTitle: How can I be less afraid of people?
questionText: I am a female and in my early teens. I don't want to feel afraid of people. When I meet someone, I know that they are okay, but I still feel afraid.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: First off, this is totally expected for someone your age!Â  You are just moving into the phase of life where your "job" is to figure out your identity and who you are.Â  It's no surprise you are afraid of people, if that's the way you feel you are struggling.If you are worried about people harming you, that paints a different picture.Â  Do you struggle to trust your evaluations of others?Â  What makes someone safe (ish) vs. potentially dangerous?Â  Sitting down and coming up with some ways you have done this in the past or qualities of the people you trust now can help to disentangle what means safety and what means danger. We can never truly know how someone will behave, but if we always choose to never trust, then we miss out on connection as well.Â Â Your brain is still growing so the great news is it's so flexible to change.Â  It remains flexible for the entire lifespan, but the teen years are really the last time it's so moldable.Â Â If there's someone in your life you can trust, reaching out for help can make how you are feeling less intense.Â  It's never fun to deal with everything by yourself.Â Â Hope this helps!

questionTitle: How can I be less afraid of people?
questionText: I am a female and in my early teens. I don't want to feel afraid of people. When I meet someone, I know that they are okay, but I still feel afraid.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Maybe the problem is learning to trust yourself to not be afraid other people!Reflect on what you believe would increase your trust of believing your own judgement on whom to trust.If you've had any type of violation during your growing up years or witnessed someone in your family be violated, emotionally, physically or through some terrible accident or incident, then you may hesitate to believe other people are safe and not to be feared.Give yourself plenty of time and reassurance that as long as you are making sincere effort to increase you comfort around other people, eventually you will succeed.

questionTitle: How can I learn to not shut down and say what's wrong with me?
questionText: When I get talked to by my dad or stepmom, or if I'm in trouble, I will begin to cry and not say what's wrong with me. When my dad or stepmom ask what is wrong, I never know the answers or the words to put together what is actually wrong with me.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: I really admire that you want to express yourself to your parents!Â  It's very normal to have fear about how to talk to a parent, let alone two at the same time.Â  Most adults don't do what you want to do.Could you come up with what you want to say to them before you are feeling upset?Â  What do you really need them to know?Â  Also, do you want your dad and stepmom to meet certain emotional needs for you?Â  Maybe they would benefit from knowing that you have a hard time expressing yourself when you are upset and can help to come up with ways to help you through that.Â  Â Perhaps you need some space from them when you are crying, or maybe you need to talk to one parent alone vs both at the same time. You don't have to wait to be upset to have these conversations either--if you feel you can approach them when things are "calm" (whatever that means for your household), it may be easier to communicate.It's important to know they may not respond the way you want.Â  It's up to you to decide if you feel safe or not to express yourself, but it seems like you want to if you are seeking an answer for this dilemma!

questionTitle: How can I learn to not shut down and say what's wrong with me?
questionText: When I get talked to by my dad or stepmom, or if I'm in trouble, I will begin to cry and not say what's wrong with me. When my dad or stepmom ask what is wrong, I never know the answers or the words to put together what is actually wrong with me.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Maybe you need more time to reflect and organize your thoughts.Try to figure out what would make you feel more relaxed about talking to your dad or stepmom.Also its possible you simply don't feel safe around either of them and so intuitively realize you're better off not talking with them about a delicate matter.Depending on whether you trust talking to dad and stepmom, you may simply wish to excuse yourself from speaking about yourself.There's no good reason to be heartfelt with people whom you don't feel are willing to accept or understand who you are.

questionTitle: How can I get over my fear of public embarrassment?
questionText: A lot of times, I avoid situations where I am to meet new people because I have a fear of embarrassing myself. I often avoid large groups of people, like parties, because I think they all constantly judge me.
therapistInfo: Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCCMental Health in a Primary Care Setting
answerText: Hello, and thank you for your question. First, I want you to know that you are certainly not alone on this issue.Â Everyone, atÂ some point in time, has a fear of public embarrassment. But for manyÂ people, this fear can becomeÂ so awful that it begins toÂ have a real negative impact on their quality of life.Â Â They willÂ try to avoid any situation that they even THINK will cause them embarrassment or anxiety. Escaping a possible embarrassing moment by avoiding or isolating may cause some relief at first, but then many times the avoidance will eventuallyÂ lead to loneliness, isolation, and even despair. By avoiding, we can also miss out on things that make us feel alive and bring enjoyment. There are many self-help books that offer advice on this issue. You can do an internet search, and I recommend reading the reviews of the book. That isÂ  great way to find out if others have found the book helpful. Another option is to seek a counselor to help you with this fear.Â I would recommend a counselor who specializes in helping people who have anxiety or social anxiety. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy isÂ  a good choice for helping with anxiety, but there are many others. The truth is that anxiety and fear of embarrassing ourselves is not something that any of us will ever "get over", but we can learn to respond to those feelings differently. A colleague may offer some other advice, as well.. Be wellRobin Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

questionTitle: How can I get over my fear of public embarrassment?
questionText: A lot of times, I avoid situations where I am to meet new people because I have a fear of embarrassing myself. I often avoid large groups of people, like parties, because I think they all constantly judge me.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: When I talk with clients about social anxiety sometimes I'll ask them what they would do if their anxiety was manageable.Â  Would you want to be more social?Â  Would that improve you quality of relationships in your life?Â  These answers can clarify what you want your life to look like and how much socialization you are truly interested in.It's normal to have thoughts and fears about what others are thinking of us, otherwise we'd be pretty shameless in our behavior!Â Â Even though we feel as though we are in the spotlight, the truth is that most people are not focused on us.Â  There's hundreds of thousands of stimuli the brain processes (especially at a party!) and you are a very small percentage of that.Â  Think about it this way--if you are at a party with a bunch of other people, why would you be in "center stage" vs anyone else at that party?Â  When people are worried about embarrassment or judgment, they typically act in ways to be less visible in public.Â  Chances are, people notice you less than they notice others simply because of avoidance behaviors.I don't think it's needed to attend every social event because who has the energy for that?!Â  But pushing yourself to engage can teach your brain that you can push yourself through these events.Â  The more you avoid, the more your brain will because the situation is something to fear.Â  If you can, stick with someone you trust or connect to.Â  That could help you to enjoy the experience more and frame it somewhat positively.If you really struggle on your own, you could visit a counselor and work on some strategies that fit for you.

questionTitle: How can I get over my fear of public embarrassment?
questionText: A lot of times, I avoid situations where I am to meet new people because I have a fear of embarrassing myself. I often avoid large groups of people, like parties, because I think they all constantly judge me.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Why not accept and tolerate that you naturally are a shy person who doesn't like large groups?This is not necessarily something to get over if it is part of who you are.People have the capacity to judge others regardless of whether the group is large or small.If you aren't afraid of being judged in small groups then study the factors which allow you to feel safe in small groups.Â Possibly you can generalize your findings to large group venues.If you try the and aren't successful, then likely you simply aren't naturally someone who cares for large group settings.Not everything a person doesn't like is a symptom of something is wrong w the person!

questionTitle: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
questionText: Iâ€™ve been on 0.5 mg of Xanax twice a day for the past month. It hasn't been helping me at all, but when I take 1 mg during a big anxiety attack, it calms me down. I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.
therapistInfo: Kaileen McMickle, MS, LPCLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: It seems like what you are looking for is a way to advocate for yourself and that's so important in mental health! You know best what is working for you and what isn't, so you are the best person to speak out for yourself to the people that can help you.Â I have extensive training in substance abuse and medications used in therapy, and I work with many people that take Xanax.Â  Counselors may not prescribe, but with the right training we can educate and help you move through the complexities of medication usage when paired with therapy.Â There's definitely some debate about using medication in the counseling world, but many people are prescribed Xanax to cope with big emotional responses.Â  We don't know much about your situation here--if you are in counseling, what types of other coping skills you've tried to use, etc., so it'd be hard to suggest not taking anything for your symptoms.Â  You are obviously struggling and sometimes stabilization is the best you can do.Â  And the fact that you are considering dealing with the attacks as an option is a sign you are willing to negotiate your dosage and maybe even the intense fear you are experiencing.Â  That's seriously so courageous.A little bit about Xanax--Xanax is a drug in the Benzodiazepine family and is fast-acting.Â  That means it does only help short-term, but your body also builds a tolerance to it pretty quickly (just as people build tolerance to alcohol).Â  That could be why they aren't as effective for you at the dosage you are taking, especially if you are prescribed to take them twice a day.Â  It's really important that you discuss the symptoms you are still having with your prescribing provider, as well as when you are taking the medications so they understand the details of your situation and can determine if or how to modify your dosage.Â  These providers know a lot about the medication process and the more info they have, the better they can meet your needs.Â  They are ultimately the ones that will work with you to decide whether or not Xanax is the best for you and your situation.I definitely understand your concern that your provider may basically take away how you cope with panic attacks.Â  That's a scary thought!Â  Prescribing providers are typically trained in detecting medication abuse, and it is very common for people with anxiety issues to request higher dosages.Â  I have had plenty of clients ask for increased dosage.Â  Not only can this get you the assistance you need at the time you need it, but give you a voice in your treatment.Â  You may end up using that same voice for request to lower your dosage in the future.I do feel an ethical duty to let you know about some of the dangers of Xanax.Â  Benzodiazepines are depressants and work on the central nervous system (CNS) to do things like slow down your heart rate, breathing, etc. (as you can feel when they do work).Â  They should never be taken with any other depressants, such as alcohol, barbiturates, and other medications in the Benzo family.Â  Combinations like these could be fatal.Another danger is that there's a common pattern of relapse after discontinuing Xanax.Â  This means that symptoms tend to come back stronger than they were before taking the drug.Â  The reason for this is because when you are taking Xanax, your brain tries to intensify your fear reaction to override the drug.Â  So when you discontinue it, your fear reactions are still at those heightened levels.Â  Your prescribing provider can talk to you more about that and/or the process of tapering off the medication to make that less likely when that time comes for you.If you are in counseling and doing exposure activities, (being exposed to things you fear and sitting through the anxiety response) Xanax does interfere with this process.Â  The brain can't learn a different response if you feel calm.Â  This is something your counselor (if you have one) can discuss with you as well.The last thing I'd like to say is that there could be some value to practicing other ways to manage your anxiety if you want to make more long-term changes.Â  That decision is completely yours!Â  If/when you feel ready to do that, a counselor can help you learn how to move through anxiety without being as reliant on Xanax.Â Â I hope this is helpful and you find what you need!

questionTitle: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
questionText: Iâ€™ve been on 0.5 mg of Xanax twice a day for the past month. It hasn't been helping me at all, but when I take 1 mg during a big anxiety attack, it calms me down. I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Do you think you're abusing xanax?It is a highly addictive drug so maybe one reason you feel compelled to take more is bc you already are addicted.Drugs don't do anything helpful in solving life's problems. Â  Once the effect wears off, the stressful situation is once again waiting for you to address it.Think over your reason for not directly asking your psychologist about upping your dose.Also, do you ever talk about your life problems with this psychologist or only your need for drugs? Â  Â The more gradual path to a better life is to not need drugs in the first place. This consists of your willingness to face the matters that are creating such terrible feelings inside you.

questionTitle: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
questionText: Iâ€™ve been on 0.5 mg of Xanax twice a day for the past month. It hasn't been helping me at all, but when I take 1 mg during a big anxiety attack, it calms me down. I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.
therapistInfo: Catherine Misita
answerText: Staying on the lower dose may give you more room to learn strategies for coping with your anxiety.Â  Medications are so helpful, and needed at times, but it's also important to have a varietyÂ of tools you use to manage your responses to stress.Â  If you are not already seeing a therapist, consider finding one who can help you learn some effective strategies, like replacing self-defeating thoughts with ones that work better for you, or mindfulness, relaxation, or other tools to keep your anxiety in the manageable range!

questionTitle: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
questionText: Iâ€™ve been on 0.5 mg of Xanax twice a day for the past month. It hasn't been helping me at all, but when I take 1 mg during a big anxiety attack, it calms me down. I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.
therapistInfo: Lauren Ostrowski, MA, LPC, NCC, BC-TMH, CCTP, CCHI tailor my therapeutic approach to each client's strengths and goals
answerText: In general, Xanax is very short-acting.Â You mentioned that you are afraid that your medical provider will take you off of the Xanax and put you on something else. If the Xanax is not working well for you, I wonder if something else may work better. What is your reasoning there? Also, sometimes there are medications that you can take in addition to Xanax.In addition to talking with your medical provider about changing the medication, try to track your levels of anxiety on a scale of 1 to 10 throughout the day so you can get a pattern of what is happening. Also consider writing down what is happening before you have anxiety attacks. This may help your medical provider know what medication may be helpful to you or what changes could be made.As far as how to discuss this with your medical provider, I would suggest mentioning the symptom changes you are having (anxiety attacks that are not helped with 0.5mg of Xanax) and ask what they would suggest that might help. If your medical provider suggests taking you off of the Xanax, I would recommend talking about the reasons why you would prefer to stay on the Xanax and what your concerns are about coming off of it. You could also ask whether anything could be combined with Xanax.There are also many other anxiety medications. I have seen lots of people that take more than one medication to lessen anxiety that they are having.I would also consider talking with a therapist (unless the person who is prescribing a medication is also doing therapy with you). Getting more information about your anxiety and how it is affecting you may be greatly helpful to you.

questionTitle: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
questionText: Iâ€™ve been on 0.5 mg of Xanax twice a day for the past month. It hasn't been helping me at all, but when I take 1 mg during a big anxiety attack, it calms me down. I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.
therapistInfo: Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCCMental Health in a Primary Care Setting
answerText: Hello, and thank you for your question. While counselors work closely with medical providers, and sometimes have discussions about medications with people, we rarely make recommendations about how much or what typeÂ of medicationÂ a person should be taking.
